newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: POLL-Singapore exports seen hurt by Seagate woes.
newsitem.headline: POLL-Singapore exports seen hurt by Seagate woes.

text.p: Singapore's trade recovery is trundling along but its weak electronics industry remains fearful of being hurt by Seagate's problems with its high-end disk drive production, economists said on Wednesday.
A Reuter survey of 12 financial institutions produced an average forecast of 6.3 percent in June nominal non-oil exports year-on-year, up from an actual one percent drop in May.
But economists sounded a note of caution, saying June's bullish figure was due largely to a low base of comparison against June 1996.
Most forecast total non-oil exports would be around the same level as May in value, around Singapore $7.4 billion.
They said uncertainty over Seagate's weaker earnings, which could hurt local output, still-sluggish personal computer sales worldwide and lower costs of computer chips were bearish factors.

Electronics account for nearly 60 percent of Singapore's non-oil exports and Seagate Technology, the world's largest disk drive manufacturer, reported weak fourth-quarter profits earlier this month, reflecting lower demand for high-end disk drives.
ABN-Amro Hoare Govett's regional economist Song Seng Wun projected a rise of 5.7 percent year-on-year, a 2.5 percent month-on-month decline.
The monthly comparative drop was attributed to prevailing softness in most export sectors.
"We're seeing more positive numbers in the electronics sector on a year-to-year basis, not because they are showing a sharp rebound but because the base was so much lower," Song said.
"If it doesn't come into positive territory (June exports) then GDP ought to be shot to pieces," he added.
Wong Keng Siong, an economist with Yamaichi Securities, predicted a nine percent rise in exports, based on assumption that trade in absolute terms would be roughly the same as in May.
"If we get something in the region of five to 10 percent, I would think the market would largely discount that number," Wong said, noting this span factored in the low base in 1996.
But others said the recovery was patchy, with both domestic export figures and U.S. electronic orders not yet showing consistent monthly increases.
"It would have to be considerably above 10 percent, closer to 12-12.5 percent, for the market to respond positively," said Prasenjit Basu of UBS Securities.
Basu said he felt the economy was on track for a year-end recovery as leading indicators pointed to strengthening. The question was when the upturn would be reflected in domestic exports.

Despite the slide in May non-oil exports, the decline was seen as less severe than the 4.1 percent contraction in the first quarter of 1997. April and May data taken together showed non-oil exports increased by 2.4 percent compared to the
corresponding two months last year.
Leading the bears, however, was MMS/Standard & Poors forecast of minus 0.5 percent.

"Sales have picked up a little bit but prices have been going down so that would upset some of the benefits from higher sales," said economist Andy Tan, noting regional exporters were concerned at the decline in prices for higher-end computer chips.
Tan said his forecast was not bleak, merely tempering overly optimistic projections for an early recovery.
"It's not bleak at all. Since the beginning of this year expectations were for a second-half recovery. Some people were optimistic and thought it could happen in the second quarter."
--Singapore newsroom (65 8703080)
